metadata.copyright_compliance: Original content based on general medical knowledge

statement.text: Tibial (infrapopliteal) disease involves the anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and peroneal arteries, is often diffuse and calcified especially in diabetics, and requires angiosome-based revascularization planning for CLTI with tissue loss.
statement.formal: Three tibial arteries: AT → DP, PT → medial/lateral plantar, Peroneal → communicating branches; Diabetic pattern: Diffuse, calcified, spared proximal; Critical: Angiosome-targeted revascularization

explanation.intuition: The tibial arteries are the final common pathway to the foot. Disease here is the defining feature of critical limb ischemia, and diabetics are particularly affected with heavy calcification that spares the proximal vessels.
explanation.key_insight: Tibial disease drives critical limb ischemia - treatment must target the angiosome feeding the wound for optimal healing.
explanation.technical_details: The three tibial arteries arise from the popliteal trifurcation: anterior tibial (becomes dorsalis pedis), posterior tibial (gives medial and lateral plantar), and peroneal (provides collaterals via communicating branches). Diabetic arteriopathy preferentially affects tibial vessels with diffuse, calcified disease. The Global Limb Anatomic Staging System (GLASS) grades infrapopliteal disease based on target artery path and landing zone. Angiosome-directed revascularization improves wound healing outcomes.
common_misconceptions: All three tibials need to be patent for foot viability - FALSE, single vessel runoff often sufficient
Peroneal alone cannot salvage the foot - FALSE, can via collaterals though less ideal
Tibial disease is always bilateral - FALSE, can be asymmetric
Endovascular tibial intervention has poor outcomes - FALSE, improved with contemporary techniques

anterior_tibial.course: Passes anteriorly through interosseous membrane, along anterior leg

posterior_tibial.course: Deep posterior compartment, behind medial malleolus

peroneal.course: Along fibula in deep posterior compartment

tibioperoneal_trunk.significance: Must be patent to access PT and peroneal

diabetic_pattern.implication: Tibial intervention often needed, but calcification challenges treatment

glass_staging.target_artery_path: Best vessel to reach wound angiosome

endovascular.tibial_stenting: Generally avoided due to occlusion risk

bypass.patency: Depends on vein quality and runoff

angiosome_targeting.principle: Direct revascularization to artery feeding wound
angiosome_targeting.benefit: Improved wound healing vs indirect revascularization
angiosome_targeting.diabetes: Angiosome targeting more important due to poor collaterals

definition.@value: Patterns of atherosclerotic disease affecting the tibial arteries, critical for CLTI management and angiosome-based revascularization.

treatment: Wound care and limb salvage protocols

learning_objectives: Identify the three tibial arteries and their angiosome territories
Describe the diabetic pattern of tibial arteriopathy
Apply angiosome principles to revascularization planning
Select appropriate endovascular vs bypass for tibial disease
clinical_pearls: Tibial disease drives CLTI - look below the knee in diabetics
Diabetic pattern: diffuse tibial disease with spared proximal vessels
Vein conduit is mandatory for tibial bypass
Angiosome targeting matters most in diabetics (poor collaterals)
Peroneal-only revasc is better than nothing but suboptimal for forefoot wounds

medicalCode.name: Atherosclerosis of native arteries of leg with rest pain
